Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Incorporating hillslope transport into laboratory landscape experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hilly and mountainous terrain has a remarkable tendency to organize itself into repeating ridges and valleys. The spacing of these landform sequences, which sets the density of drainage networks and the height of mountains, depends on the competition between advective sediment transport in channels and diffusive sediment transport on hillslopes. Despite promising results from numerical models, it is unclear how climate and tectonics modulates the relative effectiveness of hillslope and channel processes in determining landscape dissection. To test controls on these fundamental landscape properties, this research will incorporate diffusive hillslope transport into an existing laboratory model for actively eroding landscapes. Our physical experiments will generate reproducible hillslope transport via sediment incorporation in needle ice on the landscape surface while channels will evolve through precipitation from sprinklers. Because the experiments will be able to isolate and manipulate rates of hillslope and channel processes, we will document landform development under a wide range of climatic and tectonic scenarios. Furthermore, as the first physical experiment to explicitly incorporate hillslope processes, this research will track the dynamics of landform adjustment, such as ridge migration and drainage capture, in a system with relevance to much of the Earth?s surface.

Previous numerical and experimental studies of climate controls on landscape evolution generally focus on how precipitation drives channel discharge and valley incision. However, climate also modulates sediment production and transport on hillslopes through changes in periglacial processes and vegetation, profoundly affecting the topographic organization of landscapes. Results from our experimental landscape will inform efforts to decode past climate signals in topography as well as predict the effect of future climate change on landscape evolution. Physical experiments are a powerful tool for outreach and science recruitment because of their ability to reduce complex, million-year-scale processes in a real-time and highly accessible fashion. The funds will also provide for the construction of an experimental landscape apparatus designed explicitly for teaching and outreach. In addition to supporting the education of a PhD student, this grant includes research experience for students from local community colleges and provides for the development of a landscape evolution seminar for undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project had two primary goals: 1) to incorporate diffusive hillslope transport into an existing experimental landscape apparatus, and 2) to use the calibrated landscape simulator to decipher how diffusive and advective processes interact to generate characteristic ridge-valley sequences that are found in locations around the world.  These findings enabled us to more clearly connect how climate variables are encoded in landscapes as well as quantify controls on the stochasticity of erosional processes.

Co-PI Chris Ellis and the staff of the St. Anthony Falls Laboratory (SAFL) undertook refinements to an existing landscape evolution simulator recommended by graduate student Kristin Sweeney, including building and calibrating a motorized head tank and installing a drip box such that it did not interfere with the operation of the rest of the experiment. Sweeney went to SAFL in the fall of 2014 to conduct a set of experiments testing how the competition between advective and diffusive transport controls the scale of landscape dissection. The first four experimental runs focused on testing and calibrating the rainsplash apparatus and developing a workflow for alternating between advective (misting) and diffusive (rainsplash) transport. Sweeney observed that unlike in the rainsplash trials performed at a small scale in the lab at University of Oregon, rainsplash transport in the SAFL simulator was not purely diffusive. The five subsequent experimental runs systematically varied the relative contribution of rainsplash transport by varying the percentage of runtime where rainsplash was active from 0 to 100%. Each experiment was run to flux steady state, such that the average erosion rate was equal to uplift rate. Uplift and rainfall rate were held constant during each run to isolate the effect of changing the sediment transport process. In the winter of 2014-2015, Sweeney prepared an AGU talk and manuscript (later published in Science) detailing the analysis of the steady-state experimental topography and then started work on a longer manuscript using the time-lapse topography to develop transport laws for our experimental landscape. PI Roering and Sweeney also worked with a post-graduate student and the machine shop at UO to design and build a teaching model of the SAFL landscape simulator. This model, designed to be mounted on a rolling cart, simplifies the research-grade experiment by reducing the range of rainfall rates and uses a handcrank to generate uplift. They worked with colleagues in the UO geography department to collect topographic data from this model with an Xbox Kinect, which enabled them to project an image of the evolving topography in real time. They anticipate that this method of data collection will make their teaching model accessible to large introductory-level classes at UO and elsewhere.

    Using the steady-state topography generated by the five experiments detailed above, we have demonstrated that increasing the relative contribution of rainsplash transport is a robust proxy for increasing hillslope diffusivity in our experiments. We have also shown higher diffusive (rainsplash) transport results in landscapes with lower drainage density. These results match predictions of numerical models of landscape evolution, and constitute the first physical demonstration of the hillslope control on landscape scale.
